body_html:
It's atypical to do this. Folks usually build two graphs: one for
training, and a separate one for eval. (you can use a common function to
build the "common" subgraph). You then run the train and eval graphs
either in separate threads or in different processes. At the very least,
you use different sessions for training and eval.

On Thu, Oct 6, 2016 at 9:08 AM, Daniel Schonfeld notifications@github.com
wrote:

@ebrevdo https://github.com/ebrevdo the shape changed... it was my
mistake. My timing comparison was incorrect. When compared with the same
shape the timing was identical.

So now I'm just left wondering, what I asked above. How can I do both
train and eval in the same process using input ops?

—

body:
It's atypical to do this.  Folks usually build two graphs: one for
training, and a separate one for eval.  (you can use a common function to
build the "common" subgraph).  You then run the train and eval graphs
either in separate threads or in different processes.  At the very least,
you use different sessions for training and eval.

> mistake. My timing comparison was incorrect. When compared with the same
> shape the timing was identical.

> So now I'm just left wondering, what I asked above. How can I do both
